Though the first season was somewhat slow, due to having to set up the narrative, setting, and themes, the second season manages to use this eventual familiarization and kick things into high gear, providing a great blend of over-the-top action and serious, complex characters.


... Though I imagine most people could have gone without some of the on-and-on exposition at times, though of course, this is lightened up quite a bit come the second season.


OVERALL:


As a fan of the original visual novel, I'm happy to say that this is a great show for just about all of the crowds, be it fellow VN readers, fans of F/Z, and first-time viewers who want to get into the Fate franchise and believe this might be a good starting point. With a well-crafted, character-driven story that delves into the struggles that comes with being a hero that lives for nothing more than to protect, unrivaled animation in anime shows, splendid voice acting, and unforgettable sequences, Fate/stay night: Unlimited Blade Works is sure to be a pleasure to many. It stands as not only the best series of the seasons, but also, in my opinion, one of the greatest anime shows ever made.

I know that I am very late but this show is so bad that I just had to write a review anyway. Season one was a complete atrocity and still I powered through it because Fate Zero had a pretty bad first season too but it got way better in season two. Unfortunately, this is not the case for Unlimited Blade Works. Things only get worse in season two of this shit fest and Caster must've used her noble phantasm RULE BREAKER on MAL's rating system before she died because there is no way in hell that the score on here is legit when thereis so little to like about this show.\n
1/10.

If I were to describe the first season, it'd be "flawed, but still entertaining." The characters regularly acted in ways inconsistent with their established motivations, but you could always at least tell what was going on at a given moment, and the interesting possibilities of its premise, a death game between heroes all with different abilities, backed up by some pretty animation made me keep watching. Even though I didn't consider Season 1 a masterpiece or anything though, Season 2 failed to live up to it.
Its first mistake was the villain. Season 1 kept us guessing who could beat who in what situations, but Season2 introduces a new antagonist (okay, he wasn't new but he didn't matter until now) who just wipes the floor with who we thought was probably the strongest character. As well as I understand it, his powers are, "can do anything." There's just nothing interesting about that. Caster remains an antagonist from last season, and some drama with Archer, but those arcs were resolved through plot, not action, and the plot of this show is just not good.


The best I can describe the plot of this show is "stuff happens, because it says so." Every single twist in the show felt only partially justified. Unlike the first season, I often didn't quite understand what was exactly happening, and when they tried to explain it through monologues, I struggled to stay interested with all the nonsense. No seriously, the monologues in this show really suck and I hated them. I'd spend time breaking them down and explaining why they're terrible, but I can't even pretend to understand what a lot of them were trying to say, it was that incomprehensible. Oh, and there's time travel in this show, and they do not handle it well.


To be fair, there were good moments here and there. There weren't enough, but for a couple of seconds here and there, there'll be a cool bit of animation, or they'll finally shut up and play some sweet music, or Tohsaka will do something cute (yes, I fell for her too, she was annoying at times but stupidly cute at others). If they'd focused more on these and less on convoluted meta nonsense, I'd have walked away much happier, but I guess we don't always get what we want.

I am going to state this as simply as possible. When I review anime, a 7 is a 70% which means the anime was average but nothing special. I noticed most people would say that was worth a 5, or a 50%, but that is an F. If an anime didn't have any obvious flaws other than being nothing special, then I don't think it failed. So please read my reviews with this in mind. This is why most of my ratings seem on the high end. If I enjoyed it enough to finish it, it should be getting a C, not any lower.
I willwrite the exact same review for the other season, as I watched them as together as one.


Unlimited Blade works is a huge improvement upon the original anime adaptation. Everything has been improved upon. Fate Stay/Night is probably one of the best action anime I have ever watched, and is excellent from beginning to end.


Story(8/10)

The story is very well written, and even has a bit of a twist I wasn't expecting. All of the pieces come together nicely, and enough mystery is left in everything for it to remain interesting until the very end. The pacing is really fantastic with the slow build to two massive battles. It is hard to say too much more about this, except for how well executed it all was.


Art(9/10)

I can't make this very long, because I think everyone already knows how gorgeous this anime is. Th character design is solid, the environments are detailed, the world is colorful, and the animation during battles is incredible.  Finally, the special effects are absolutely breathtaking. 


Sound(8/10)

This is probably the least noticed gem of the series. The music is so good. It keeps the pacing and the atmosphere just right throughout the anime. Not only that, but on its own, the music is still amazing, I can see myself listening to it outside of the show, and that should say something.


Character(8/10)

The characters are all so well developed. They all have deep backstory and unique personality. You will grow to love each of them as the show carries forth. I believe its strongest point is opening it to historical figures. I found myself interested in each hero enough to look them up and read about them, which really added to the history of the show.


Enjoyment(8/10)

The show is absolutely gripping. Everything that I have mentioned before makes this a really fun anime to watch. The battles will have you on the edge of your seat, the characters will have you questioning yourself, and the plot will keep you interested.


This show easily deserves the 9 that I gave it. I usually make this last paragraph recommending it to a certain group or telling them to stay away. However, to be honest, I can't think of anyone who wouldn't enjoy this anime. I will leave you with that.

Seven wizards each summon a legendary warrior from history or myth and fight to the death for the Holy Grail... How on earth do you manage to make that premise so BORING? Ufotable's follow-up to their blockbuster hit 'Fate Zero' fails to bring repeat success.
-Story-
If there was one thing 'Unlimited Blade Works' lacked it would be 'momentum'. The story takes its sweet time to get anywhere, and there were a couple times when I would sit through several minutes
of two hostile characters just standing and talking before I had the sickening realization that they weren't going to fight this episode- the exposition and desperate attemptsto be philosophical had used up too much time. For comparison, 'Fate Zero' had it's fair share of plot-extending tricks such as characters deciding not to continue for a fight for vague 'tactical' reasons (a trope that's badly abused here in UBW), but with camera constantly moving between seven different teams it still seemed like something was happening. UBW seems content to follow around Shirou, Rin, Saber, and Archer while they dither about around the school and the other 5 teams are often nowhere to be seen. This

story is plain and simply slow.


-Characters-


Inconsistent plot devices and philosophical mouthpieces. They act solely in accordance with the needs the story, and often make face-palm worthy decisions because of it. Unfortunately, the worst examples of this come near the end of the story so I don't want to give away big spoilers (let's just say Rin is a repeat offender, and Lancer and Saber have their own moments as well). Or, for a less spoiler-iffic example, the whole reason Shirou survives long at all is because Rin decides to help him despite his being the easiest target and least useful ally out of all the mages in the Holy Grail War because she has a crush on him. Shirou loses any chance at

being an inspiring or likable hero because his final realization comes across at fatalistically accepting what might happen rather than adapting his approach in any way. He just seems stubborn, unable to give a clearly articulated reason as to why he would continue to do the exact same thing even when he knows the probable result. So the characters are clear miss as well, uninteresting and dull.


-Art and Sound-


There's a reason this show had the nickname 'Unlimited Budget Works'- it looks and sounds BEAUTIFUL. I won't waste much time here except to say the animation is jaw-dropping (especially on the rare occasions when characters actually fight) and the sound is excellent. Ufotable's 'Fate' adaptations always seem to have killer OP's and the two in UBW are no exception. 


-Enjoyment-


At first I watched this with high expectations. Then I watched it with macabre fascination, the same way as one would watch a train wreck, as the writing went ever more down the toilet. Don't go into this show expecting anime's magnum opus and you'll probably enjoy this well enough.


-Overall-


This anime looks and sounds great, but is a catalog of writing errors. Good for dumb fun.

Fate stay/night unlimited blade works review (both seasons together)
– SPOILER ALERT: THERE MAY BE SOME SMALLER OR BIGGER SPOILERS IN HERE, ALTOUGH I TRY TO KEEP IT TO A MINIMUM --
First of all, this is my first review, so don't be too harsh if my lack of experience shows.
I will be reviewing this anime based on the following elements:
1) Enjoyability (the most important one in my book)
2) Characters/story
3) Art
4) Sound/music
Enjoyability
I enjoyed this anime very much overall. This is off course very subjective, but to me personally the story was very engaging and quite unpredictable. I had not expected a lot of the twists in thestory, for example the servants summoned by the masters turned out to have way more free will and autonomy then I had expected.


The fights scenes were very tense and enjoyable, and the interactions between the charactes were fun as well. I regularly found myself unable to stop 'before watching one more episode'. For overall enjoyment, I rate this a 9/10.


Characters/story


As said above, the story really kept me interested in the show. Especially during the last five episodes of the second season , I just could not stop watching. At it's core , I believe it is a story about what happens to a single person who tries to always do what is good for others in a world in which most people care more about themselves and maybe their immediate friends and family. We see this in the person of Archer, the servant, who is the future version of the main character and is bitter and depressed about the path this way of live put him on. He is forced to clean up for other people's mess all the time and fight enless battles to this end. Because humans keep making mistakes and keep doing evil things to meet their selfish ends, he never actually comes closer to achieving his ultimate goal of creating a perfect world where everyone can lead a happy life.


The story revolves around the Holy Grail War, a war which takes place once in a number of decades and involves seven master mages fighting for the holy grail using servants. Each master summons one servant. The master whose servant is the last one too live wins the war and the right to have his or her wish granted by the omnipotent Holy Grail. There are a number of different masters, all of which have their own reasons for wanting to use the power of the Grail. Some wishes are benevolent, some are evil. The fight for the grail provides a lot of exciting moments and fights in the story, and always remains interesting, and as such is a good basis for the plot of the series. This is also true after it is revealed in the second half of the second season that all might not be as it seems when it comes to the Grail and what it really is.


The characters of some of the servants and the six other masters are also explored in depth. They are of different character and all their character types are logical and realistic. Even Gilgamesh, the main villain of the series, is not completely insane, but has his own reasons to want to do the evil deeds he wants to do, which are understandable from his perspective. This makes him an interesting character. The other servants and masters are interesting as well, but not all get as much attention as Emiya, Rin, Saber, Archer, and Gilgamesh because their roles in the story are not that big or they die off early (like Berserker for example). I would want to write more about the characters and story, but I am afraid I would spoil too much for it to be acceptable under the site's review rules. Let 's just say there are very interesting and captivating, and a big part of why I enjoyed the story.


Art


This anime clearly had a big budget, because it looks really good. The art style is not unique, the series uses the standard 'modern anime art style', but in a very beautifull, detailed manner. There is good usage of lightning, facial expressions, etc to convey emotions in certain scenes, and the whole series is just very easy on the eye. The fight scenes especially are very nicely and fluently animated and are very energetic. They are a feast to look at and make the show a lot of fun. The backgrounds of scenes and stillshots are also very nice, with lots of tiny details drawn in which make the series look less bland then certain other anime, and again goes to show this was made by an experienced studio with a high budget.


Sound/music


The endings and openings of both seasons are not my favourite, I tend to like my openings more cute/happy/hyperactive, but such songs would off course not have fitted the story and overall tone of this show. The music in the episodes however was great. It effectively (like the art) conveyed emotions such as sadness, happiness, excitement etc. At certain times, it blended in so well with the show that I almost stopped noticing it was there.


The sound... is the sound. It's good, which mostly means that I did not notice anything odd or off about the way things sounded to tell me it was not good. Voice acting  (I watched the Japanese version) was good, fight sounds were good, etc. It's perfectly fine, nothing more to be said really.


Conclusion


Overall, I really enjoyed the show because of the interesting story with the unexpected plot twists, the suspense, the cool fight scenes, the interesting characters, and the beautifull animation. I recommend anyone to watch the show if they're at all interested in action and/or fantasy anime shows. I rate it a 8/10 overall.

NOTE: This review is for both seasons of Fate/Stay night(FSN): Unlimited Blade Works(UBW). This review will be making some comparisons to both of DEEN's FSN anime, the visual novel, and Ufotable's Fate/Zero(F/Z) anime, though I will do my best to avoid spoilers from those works as there are people who decided to start their journey into Type-Moon/Fate with this anime series. For those who care, I got into the franchise with the FSN visual novel and have read all currently translated fate works.
UBW, and Fate in general, is a story in a setting many anime viewers are already familiar with by now, as FSN isarguably the most popular and well known Visual Novel, and has had many successful(at least in terms of popularity and sales) anime based on it and its spinoffs. It is based in the setting of the Holy Grail war ritual, a battle royal where seven mages each summon a familiar called a servant to battle for them. Each familiar is placed into one of seven unique classes, Saber, Archer, Lancer, Caster, Rider, Berserker, and Assassin, and each servant is based on a famous hero of myth, such as your typical Greek Heroes from stories like the Iliad or the Odyssey like Odysseus. Each servant is also gifted with a weapon(or weapons) associated with their myth called a noble phantasm, and then given abilities based on the feats they performed there and the class they are summoned into, but to go into more detail about this would be beyond the scope of the review and best experienced watching the story. The winner of this battle royal will gain the right to obtain the holy grail, and as such have any wish they desire granted. The story of UBW, and FSN as a whole, is set in the 5th holy grail war.


For those who hear the word "visual novel" and immediately think "Does that mean it's going to have sex in it?" FSN is a visual novel that has been rereleased with an all ages version, and that is the version of the story UBW choose to follow, so the one sex scene normally found in UBW is not found here. For those planning to watch the Heaven's Feel movies, I cannot make any such promises about those films in regards to sexual content. For those worried that UBW might still be filled with fanservice of the ecchi nature, UBW doesn't really have any more than your typical anime does.


Ufotable's adaptation of UBW is an anime in a very awkward position. For starters, it already received an adaptation in the form of a movie in 2010, about five years ago at the time of writing it. As such, in addition to the original source material already being very famous and well known, many people already know the core story of the route and its many twists, despite how poor of an adaptation the original movie was. Secondly, it is an adaptation of a medium notorious for receiving poor adaptations, the visual novel. Visual novels(VNs) are stories that generally make heavy use of multi branching/narrative story lines and as such stories of this format do not translate well into anime because anime generally rely on a single chance to tell a story while VNs are usually packages of stories that all build on top of each other. As a result, there are often things only told in one route of a story, such as character development, themes, and of course the main plot of the route, that will be missed out on by only adapting one route of the story into an anime. While there are visual novels that do not rely on multi route story telling such as the When they Cry series, Utawarerumono, and Steins;Gate, FSN is not one of them. 


This brings us to the next point of UBW's awkward position as an anime adaptation: it is the second route of a VN where the story is told in sequential order. While most VNs are told such that you have some choice on how to proceed with the story into each route, the FSN VN forces you to play the game in the order of the Fate route(what the old DEEN anime was based on), UBW(what this anime and DEEN's old move is based on), and finally Heaven's Feel(HF, what Ufotable's movies will be based on). As a result of UBW being an adaptation of the second route, it assumes that you are already aware of details from the first route, Fate. Such details include more development for characters who get little to no screen time in UBW, resolutions of themes and character arcs, a better explanation of how certain characters magic and abilities work, and general foreshadowing and world building. As the old anime adaptation of the Fate route is of very low quality (other than the OST) and is a poor adaptation of the Fate route, most anime only watchers are generally warned to avoid it and thus miss out on details from the route if they choose not to watch it or read the story in the VN.


With that said, this also brings us to the final point of awkwardness, Ufotable's adaptation of F/Z. F/Z, released in 2006,  is a prequel to FSN, released in 2004, and was originally a light novel. Ufotable adapted this prequel to FSN back in 2011, and the anime was met with much critical acclaim and success, the result of which can be said to have contributed to Ufotable making this anime and the movie adaptation of HF currently in production. It also introduced a new group of fans to the franchise who only started with the anime F/Z. Because of this, many anime only watchers go into UBW thinking that they will be getting the sequel to F/Z. To be blunt, UBW is not the sequel to F/Z, and the same can be said of FSN as a whole. Of the three routes in FSN, UBW is the one with the least amount of connection to all the plotlines "left" from F/Z. Additionally, as F/Z was based off of a light novel told from only one story/narrative, it adapts much better into anime form as it tells its story all in one go without needing to wait for others to fill you in on all the details. If you go into UBW expecting the sequel to F/Z, chances are you're going to be disappointed, as FSN was not structured to follow after FZ, but rather FZ was designed to build off what you know of FSN. As a side note, of the three routes, HF is the one with the most connection to F/Z, but even it doesn't wrap up everything and leaves some details to only be concluded in the Fate route. As such, if you started with F/Z, and are looking forward to a version of FSN that works as the sequel to F/Z, you'll likely enjoy HF the most, however this does not mean you won't be able to enjoy UBW.


One other difference to note about FSN when compared to F/Z is that unlike F/Z, FSN has an air of mystery to its story telling. FSN makes (primarily in the Fate route) makes heavy use of foreshadowing and there are many details that are presented in the story that don't fully become clear and apparent until much later on in the route, or even in another route entirely.


With all this in mind, it shows that Ufotable clearly had quite the challenge ahead of them in creating this anime. Personally, I believe the people who will get the most enjoyment out of the UBW anime are people who were already long time Fate fans, as UBW makes many small references to all the major Fate works, and while the anime is still strong enough to be enjoyed as you like, the lack of knowledge from the Fate route can hurt your. This is key, as the thing to keep in mind about UBW, and FSN as a whole, is that the whole story is only told when you look at each route together in one picture.


But enough background, lets get to the meat of the review. UBW tells the story of Emiya Shirou(or Shirou Emiya when translated) and his dream of becoming a hero of justice using the setting of the 5th holy grail war to tell it. As the plot is central to his character, the viewers enjoyment of the series will be proportional to how much they like him. Shirou is a character who is also in a very awkward position. While he is a very popular character in Japan and has constantly ranked very well in Type-Moon popularity polls there, he has in some ways not enjoyed the same level of popularity in the western anime community as a result of his portrayal in DEEN's FSN anime where people mistakenly interpret his actions as being sexist in nature, in addition to being the face of the "People die when they're kill" meme. While he is also not very well liked in the Fate route of the VN as well, his character is much more popular among visual novel readers starting with his portrayal in the UBW route(or the church scene of the Fate route depending on who you ask). The Shirou in UBW goes through a completely different development than the Fate route, so if you didn't like him there, there is a chance you will find his character more enjoyable in UBW, and for those worried about his character being sexist, he in no way comes across as such a character in UBW. Where as the Fate route lays out the ground work for Shirou's mental state and desires, UBW is the first route to truly dive in and challenge his ideals, doing so in quite the brilliant manner as Shirou is forced to confront the hypocrisies of his dream along with where it will lead him. While Ufotable's portrayal of his character is of course lacking compared to the VN, they still do a very good job getting the core points of his character across, and the way he is handled in the 2nd half of the show is much better than the first half. I believe that Shirou manages to successfully come across as an interesting character in Ufotable's adaptation and that they do a good job at setting up his journey for the eventual comparisons in his character the viewer will be able to make with who he is in HF.


While the story mostly focuses on Shirou and his ideal, there are still other characters that play important roles in the story. Shirou's servant, Saber, his classmate, Rin, and Rin's servant, Archer, make up the core cast of our heroes for the story. Saber is arguably the most famous character in FSN as a whole, but for UBW she is one whose development and ideals were already explored in the Fate route, so her role in UBW is not as large as it was there. The viewers knowledge of the Fate route will enhance their enjoyment of Shirou's central conflict, as Saber's situation as a character ties into his own with events discussed later on in the story, but otherwise Saber sticks to typical servant duty and is described by the creators as being more of an observant parent in this route. As FSN was still based on a VN with dating elements in it, Rin takes the role this time as the lead heroine. Rin is a character famed for her tsundere tendencies and Zettai Ryouiki (look up the term if you aren't familiar with it), but despite being the heroine and her role is similar to what it was in the Fate route. As an expert mage who is already arguably superior in skill and knowledge compared to her father, she typically takes the role of a sort of "know it all" and explains world building aspects and events to the viewer, in addition to acting as Shirou's ally and teacher in the war. However, since the Fate route, our introduction, is over her role as a know it all and teacher is slightly reduced in exchange for her taking more actions as Shirou's ally in the war. Lastly, we have Archer. Archer is a character whose identity you do not learn in the Fate route and spends most of that route injured sneaking in moments of sheer coolness/GARness, but UBW is finally his chance to shine as he takes center stage as the most important servant of the route, with even more badassness to throw around, arguably being more important to the story than Rin at times. His character comes in direct conflict with Shirou's ideals and the conflict between them can be described as the highlight of the story.


On the antagonist side of things, UBW follows the same pattern as Fate with there being three arcs of antagonists our heroes deal with(though UBW may arguably have four depending on how you view the story of episodes 4-8). For spoiler reasons, I will not discuss the last two arcs, but I will say that these arcs primarily focus on challenging Shirou's ideals and him putting them into practice. For the first arc and most of UBW, the antagonist is the servant Caster. As obvious from the name, Caster is an expert mage whose strategies and methods of warfare are far superior to even the expert strategists of F/Z, and she herself is more inline with what one would think of when thinking of a Caster class servant unlike the one in F/Z. For those coming from F/Z, everything about her defenses and strategies can be pretty jarring, especially when you meet her master. While Caster's story doesn't tie too much into Shirou's story, she does lay the groundwork for the inherent conflicts with his ideals to become apparent and gives the viewer some interesting perspectives on morality as although she is an antagonist, her actions are still not as bad as some of the others around her and she herself has a very understandable and sympathetic wish. Another reoccurring antagonist is Shinji. Shinji's role in UBW is not as large as it was in the Fate route as he spends most of UBW coming across as more cartoony than as a threat, but he still manages to be a character that you will hate as a person due to how much of an asshole he is. While Shinji actually does have some background as a character that explains why he's an asshole(it doesn't justify his actions), Ufotable choose to skip over any of his back story, likely because he plays a larger role as an antagonist again in HF, so he ends up being more of an asshole.


In the grand scope of things, UBW focuses on a very small cast of core characters. In my opinion, the anime does an excellent job at fleshing out the characters central to this route and there are many things to be learned and discussed from their actions. UBW also has some minor characters, masters, and servants that get some focus in the story, but most of these characters do not get much development, but what development they do get can be pretty interesting. For those worried about any characters that did not get much development in this route, these characters all play a much larger and more important role in HF so look forward to seeing them in action then.


While the characters, their conflicts, and relations to each other are what drive the plot of UBW, the other key thing to UBW that most people want to see are the action scenes! Ufotable is a studio that became famous for their beautiful artwork and animation presented in their adaptations of Kara no Kyoukai and Fate/Zero, and UBW largely continues that trend and of course surpassing its predecessors in certain areas. UBW has fantastic artwork and coloring that makes the anime look much more visually appealing that F/Z, though the character designs can be a bit lacking at times, noticeably the noses. Another problem with UBW is that the CGI used has not really improved much since F/Z. Regardless, the animation is still top notch for a TV series, easily surpassing the most well animated scenes of F/Z in the first episode alone. When it comes to displaying the servants innate abilities and skills, UBW does a much better job of displaying these abilities visually than F/Z, notably a certain characters instinct skill. In general, the choreography is much better and more exciting to look at. Ufotable's job at handling this area of the show is so well done that it alone makes the series worthy watching as was the case with its predecessor. The climatic battle of UBW in particular was handled phenomenally and was easily one of the best action scenes I've ever seen in any anime.


Finally, for the last part of the review, we will discuss sound. UBW is a bit lacking in the sound department and this is the weakest aspect of the show. The main problem with the music is that it plays at too low a volume. While the BD's have apparently raised the volume of the songs, it can be very hard to hear or notice the tracks being played at times, but the tracks themselves can be pretty great at times. Another nice thing about the music is that almost every scene has custom tailored music, so you don't have to deal with the same small amount of songs getting repeated over and over again. This was a problem with F/Z as hearing "battle to the strong", while a good song, again during the climactic battle of the story instead of something new wasn't very exciting. 


The voice acting in the anime is also pretty phenomenal. Many of the VAs, particularly Shirou, Shinji, and Assassin's VA's, give the best performances they've given yet in any Fate works they've appeared in. Additionally, a certain Golden Haired character has leagues better voice work than his portrayal in both of DEEN's anime where he comes across as more cartoony, but in UBW he feels more serious and dignified.


All in all, UBW is a pretty great anime with tons of things to offer for everyone. Great animation, amazing action, intriguing characters, and top tier world are the main highlights. As a huge fan of the visual novel, I was extremely satisfied with the end result we got, though I will admit there are some parts of the series I wish were better portrayed. The pacing of the second half was not as great as I would have liked it to be. There were some episodes that were too drawn out while others would have benefited from being hour long episodes instead of half hour long ones. There were also a bunch of small nitpicky details that were missing here and there, but I think most of them are things that would only bother hardcore VN readers as opposed to more casual anime viewers.


In conclusion, I rate Ufotable's adaptation of UBW a 9/10, and certainly think of it as one of the best visual novel adaptation out there. For those who wish to read the VN for a deeper experience of the story, feel free to do so, but for those who want a more casual experience of UBW, the anime is an excellent adaptation that will do a great job getting the viewer ready for analyzing HF.

To start, I would like to say that if you are a real fan of Fate/Zero, you'll be a little disappointed, if you really expect it to be better than the Fate/SN from 2006... But, what to expect from it ?
First of all, for the ones who didn't see other routes of Fate, it's not a remake from the 2006's Fate/SN, it's just another route, so that explains why it's different in some ways the character takes along the anime. 
Now, I'll show my opinion about it, since the first Fate/SN, The normal and logical rule is " Masters against masters and servants agains servants";but why ? It's simple, servants are HEROES, warrios, they are trained for it, and master are humans, they need servants to win the war, and that's why humans can't beat servants. Fate/SN UBW broke this rule, because of the overpower protagonist, Shirou is a guy that defeated the most incredible servants of all times AND himself as a HERO. That sounds impossible, but it's a little uncomfortable for people who are expecting a new Kiritsugu in the world. I'm not saying that he HAS to be weak, only that he appears more as a student than a awesome warrior...\n\n
I noticed as well that it put all the characters more powerful than the other series, with an INCREDIBLE AGILITY... yes, this is a uncomfortable thing too, the servants and some masters ( like Shirou ) gained the ability to move faster than normal people, you can notice this on the fighting scenes. Although i like fast characters ( like Kiritsugu and kirei on Fate/Zero ), the exaggerated speed made me think I was watching a typical shounen anime, where it's very common. The difference is that on Fate/Zero, the fastest characters are trained to it, it's an ability, it means, AN EXPLANATION.\n\n
Fate/SN UBW had beautiful scenes, good moments and a good enjoyment in some episodes, the art and sound are awesome and very clear, but the story ( in my opinion ) lost for the Fate/SN from 2006. In general, it is a good anime and it was worth to watch. I didn't expect it to be brilliant as Fate/Zero, but it let me down a bit.

Unlimited Botched Works. No seriously, that's what this show is. For reference, I've only watched Fate/Zero and half of the DEEN adaptation of Fate/Stay Night before this, and I was left pretty disappointed. 
First, the visuals. You may expect me to praise them to death, but I won't. Don't get me wrong, the gradients and textures are polished to a remarkable degree, and the CGI implementation is flawless, but there's more to visuals than just the technical side. The artistic side is what falls flat, which is a shame considering it's ufotable. Where Fate/Zero had plenty of sharp edges to its objects and harsh shadowsto enhance its dark tone, UBW just looks shiny, which doesn't contribute to any specific themes from the show. Not to mention most of the fighting animation flies by so quick you can't see anything that's going on. When there's no fighting, it's even worse. Camera angles and character animations during conversations are usually pretty bland and static, and something about the faces in the characters just scream a lack of detail. So even though the show looks super shiny, it was honestly really boring to watch, due to the artistic elements coming short. Music is decent but there aren't too many memorable tracks this time around.


So what is this show even trying to accomplish? I... don't know. That's by far UBW's biggest problem; ufotable (or whoever was in charge) seemed to want to do everything, but it just doesn't combine into a coherent show. Does it want to follow-up Fate/Zero? That can't be, because of the large tone difference and how it doesn't try to neatly wrap up character arcs lingering from the previous series. Does it want to be a standalone work? No, there's too many references to Fate/Zero. A faithful adaptation of the visual novel? No, there's too many important anime-exclusive arcs and scenes. A lighthearted moe dating simulator with every girl digging Shirou? No, because there's too much edgy stuff; but it can't be a serious and dark show either because there's too much out-of-place moe or other shlock bogging it down. The writing for this UBW is truly incompetent, and the characters are victims of this. 


Ohhhhh boy, the characters. To give my full thoughts, I'll need to spoil, but let me make a sweeping statement and say that they're not very good. At all. They're just a flawed concept overall; especially our two heroes. The characters with potential don't receive enough time to be fleshed out before biting the dust either.


(SPOILERS AHEAD)


Let's start with Rin. She joins a brutal war that she knows took her father's life and risks her own for.... fun? You're kidding, right? Not even to win the grail? She's also supposed to be a cool-headed and intelligent mage, but behaves like a five year old when around Shirou. Any competent tactician should not get flustered so easily and have "tsundere" as such a big part of their thought process. It's not cute, it's aggravating; especially when their romance goes nowhere. At the end she LIVES WITH Shirou and yet they still aren't in a proper relationship, considering Luvia still believes she has a chance. Why does Rin even like Shirou? She even tried to literally kill him at one point, and legitimately threatened his life on other occasions. Rin is just a horrible concept of a character, which is a problem considering she's our main heroine. 


Shirou? You've already heard the horror stories of him. He's excruciatingly naive and idealistic, and still largely retains his ideals despite being proven wrong on too many instances to count. The fact that he says "just because you're correct doesn't mean you're right" (if there's no translation errors) proves this. When he's not frustrating to watch, he's boring. Most of his dialogue consists of platitudes. Needless to say, I don't ship Shirou and Rin. 


Archer was decent but should've been the main antagonist. Gilgamesh basically hijacks the plot from him even though he's a far less thematically relevant villain. There's no debating with him, he'll just toy with you and then impale your body. While an entertaining villain, he's a poor fit for this show. Caster was pretty good though, she really does feel like a genuine threat considering how many times she thwarts our heroes and even steals Saber. Oh that's right, Saber! She's boring and lacks the strong sense of chivalry she had in Fate/Zero. When Saber lost, I didn't feel a thing, because she was always just kinda there. Didn't do much on her own accord; just followed orders with a straight face. At least Saber's good waifu material, right? Well, UBW thinks so, considering the completely pointless bride dress she was forced to wear. Ilya and Berserker also had potential, but really needed more than just one episode to develop their characters. Lancer is cool but you don't really get to know him much. Almost everyone else isn't worth mentioning. Their motives are so unclear and resolution so unfulfilling that it's obvious the writers didn't care, so why should I?  


(SPOILERS END) 


I apologize for the length of this review, but it was a long time coming. It really pains me to say that UBW is an immensely disappointing show. The only reason I don't give it a less-than-mediocre score is because of the visual polish and a few great scenes and episodes such as the 3rd or 10th ones that built up tension really well. But really, if you loved Fate/Zero and want a followup, or experienced the visual novel and want it done justice, don't bother. Leave those memories untainted. Newcomers will also be confused due to all the references to the Fate franchise's expansive lore. Please don't watch UBW; it's not a bad show, but it's so frustratingly average (or even worse) that it'll only waste your time.

*Spoiler Free* Short Review after binge watching the entire series [ ep0-24 ] 
Fate/Zero was one of my favourite anime , felt like 'end' and 'continuation' of the characters from F/Z to F/sn was unsatisfying.

All of you fanboys, this low grade, along with my annoyance, is as much your fault as is writer's! You made me expect a masterpiece, yet this is but a single stairstep above your everyday fantasy shounen. I kinda hated the writing, as I found it had a plethora of bad writing indicators, such as lack of foreshadowing and various asspulls. It felt like everything was happening for the sake of the plot, rather than it being a natural progression of events. I'll have to go into spoilers to continue: 
SPOILERS AHEAD: 
Perfect example of how bad the writing this had, was the death andepisode of Illya. First she appears early on, just to play the cliche as all hell card of villain who will not defeat the good guys now but will come back some other time because reasons. Then she's pointlessly totally gone from the plot for the longest time, not because that would make sense, but because the plot demanded it,... just to be back for her death episode. So since writers didn't think any of this through they were like ''oh shit we forgot to develop her character or make her relevant in any way, quick, throw in a tearjerker flashback deathflag just before we murder her to get the viewers to care and get emotional''. This is just one example of some of the cheapest writing I've ever seen. And to find this in a show that is hailed as a masterpiece from one the most esteemed VN franchises of all time, just blew my mind. 


 I probably shouldn't even go into how little sense plot logic makes, with the Shirou Archer causal relationship and whatnot. But I wouldn't let mere plot logic ruin things for me,... rather it was Shirou's character arc that did it. Disregarding the fact he should have died in nearly every single episode, the story practically becomes about his internal conflict of wanting to be the hero of justice. Excuse me while I turn off this shounen red alert that just went of..... *click* there we go, now I can hear myself think again. Conflict where he is ''forced'' to face the fact that facing the fact that he can't save everyone (cause saving someone sometimes means not saving someone else) will make him lose track of this childhood ideal of his. Yes, read that sentence again. No, it still doesn't make sense. Plus it's somewhat of an irresponsible message hinting that change, as in growing up and changing your mind, is bad. While this can be an interesting and meaningful theme, I can't imagine it being dealt with worse than here. It basically came down to not wanting to grow up being a good thing somehow? Otaku pandering much? Like, suppose your adult self traveled back in time and told you you're wrong about some things. You'd be sane to believe him right? Providing you know the situation to be genuine. But no, not in Fate universe. Here, spouting shounen nonsense at your older self actually makes you fight stronger! Ooh, our shounen protagonist has to deal with drama and character development and whatnot... oh wait, that doesn't automatically make said drama and development any good whatsoever. Who would have thought? And by the way, your reward for being a dumbass shounen protagonist is this super awesome girl that likes you because this was originally a servicey VN in which heroine has to fall for the protagonist regardless of it making sense.


Not that I mind having romance, in fact, watching Rin be Rin and go all tsun tsun in various SoL situations pretty much made the show. Well, that and the out of this fucking world animation and production budget. Based ufotable. You made this clusterfuck of a story watchable and occasionally really enjoyable, kudos. You deserve Mt.Fuji sized cookie.


And to go on a slight tangent: Fate/Zero on the other hand is basically Urobuchi saying ''oh look, cool premise, let's see how it would look if writing didn't suck''. But even then, fantasy shounen-ish setting can only get you so far, hence why first season for both is a bit disappointing, mainly due to all the status quo-ing. Zero gets rather awesome in second season, while UBW tries to get awesome but falls flat on it's face, still somehow managing to at least stay interesting enough. Actually the reason I enjoyed second season/half of UBW a bit more is due to both more pretty action, and story becoming more complicated, so keeping track of all the nonsense that's going on was actually rather amusing. Plus the nonsense got even more nonsensical, in a ''so bad it's good'' kinda way.

FSN- Unlimited Blade Work is a thrilling romance-action-fantasy in a world where magic is possible and about the grail war, a battle royale which involve 7 servants and masters, each given their own unique abilities
Before i start this review, i want to point out some things
- I didnt know and didnt play the VN so this review is complete anime based
- Before i watched this anime, i completed fate zero 1st and give it 10/10 instantly, so expect to see some comparisons.
- Expect to see some light and huge spoiler ahead, ill give a warning so dont worry
- My opinion is not biased just becausei watched FZ before, all the opinion mentioning FZ here is just my personal preferences


Story - 6

The story focuses on 4 protagonist, that is Saber, Archer, Shirou and Tohsaka. The setting is your usual high school anime, BUT there is an extra fantasy tags and the story is about the grail war, to make any wishes come true the "master" such as shirou and tohsaka fight for it. All of the main characters get their story well done. Archer become badass and ALMOST make him my favourite character. The story is very unique, that you could not simply forget this anime without pointing the grail war, each servant has their own ability and its fun to see how each one of them fight.


Aaaaaand yes there is romance. The romance between shirou and tohsaka give no problems to me at all but the progression between them is boring, and there is no dramatic moment in it. I did not say it is bad, but... yes it become so dull at the end that i forget there is any progression at all, 


*SPOILER ALERT*


Plot holes, whoa i could point out many here but since it will become a HUGE spoiler i will point out here :

 *SPOILER ALERT**SPOILER ALERT**SPOILER ALERT**SPOILER ALERT*


1. Archer death and the way he return. I would be fine if the anime producers just give some explanations like archer escaped at that short amount of time but they don't

2. Gilgamesh getting eaten by the grail. I might look stupid because i dont understand it, but i really dont understand it and they didnt give any explanation at all. The reason he is eated,... so the grail war can continue? or so the grail live or what???? seriously guys

3. Once more, When kotomine kirei appeared again at the scene with lancer, if he isnt dead AGAIN they didnt give us explanation why, caster, can let that guy live

4. Lancer's master. " Oy what about his master?" "i dont care, let's progress the romance even farther!" - Producer


- SPOILER OFF -


Other than that i would like to point out that Fate Zero is really interesting anime with a great character development between EACH of 7 servants and master, in here the one whos getting development are just a pair of masters and a pair of servant.


And the ending, idk why but it is unsatisfying for me.


The pacing is also a bot off with me, its too slow for me, not worth 25 episodes at all. Most of the time they're just talking bout strategy. Nearly each episode of the second half have the MC monologue about 3 mins maybe? well i didnt count it but that is boring, because the monologue is always about the same thing over and over again.


So with that many plot holes ,uninteresting romance, i will give it 6, even tho its an interesting and unique story, the executions is really bad. And if you found an answer to the holes i pointed out above please explain , please do so


Art-10

Well this art is one, no, the best art in whole anime i've ever seen and the battle scenes look 3d. Its really cool when saber fight with any of the servant.


Sound- 9

No complain here, the sound is great.


Character -7

The characters, how i describe it... umm there are some i like and some i... didnt know. At some first episodes, rider didnt even fight at all and die(no, i will not give any spoiler alert because her die is meaningless). Lancer is badass at some first episodes but get uninteresting later on. But there are also some good characters in this series: Gilgamesh( NO IM NOT JOKING), Archer and Shirou.

1 more thing about character in FZ that i want to appear in this series.. that is Waver and Kirei. Oh i forget kirei appear in this series... 


Comparisons aside i'd like to give the characters 7 because beside all of the bad explanation on characters, there are also good ones and our mc get most development which is good


Enjoyment - 5.5

If i'd compare the enjoyment with this series and FZ, i will give it 4 but comparisons aside 6 is enough for this anime. There are no comedy( i mean "funny" one) in school life and teen setting which make it feel more Thrilling and cool IF the series itself SERIOUS in giving the atmosphere at all. Romance is bad in this series imo, its one of the worst aspect. Saber, a character that i'd like to see her development in this series didnt get any, despite all the talk in FZ with rider, she never give any objection about shirou, such as choosing "hero of justice" path that she choose and she failed. I'd like to see an episode where shirou and saber fight or just simply argue because of that, but it didnt.


Overall - 7

+Great OP and art save the overall score for me

+Each of the main character is likeable and the 2 "core" character got many development


-Story is executioned bad. Unique idea but the execution is bad.

-Except Ilyasviel, every other character beside 4 main didnt get any development

(my personal preferences)

-They didnt give a fuck about the grail war 10 years ago, they should.

This is simply a bad adaptation. Shirou is generic instead of being a subtly unhinged/mentally ill guy. Rin acts like a generic tsundere instead of a mature person who can actually hold a conversation. Lots of time is wasted showing characters like Caster when they should have spent the run time conveying Shirou's psychological characterization from the VN. Archer's lines make no sense because Shirou's inner thoughts are never conveyed. The translation quality is terrible. Three episodes are spent having Shirou, Archer, and Saber repeat the same lines at each other. The action scenes are flashy and meaningless, they do not convey any of thefascinating thoughts Shirou had during them.\n\n
I recommend the Japanese VN (not the terrible fan translation) for those interested in proper characterization and dialogue over flashy visuals.

I want to start by saying I really like this anime.
I´ll try to be as objective as I can but we all tend to be subjective when we like something and also remember this is my humble opinion about season 1 and 2 and It´s only about the anime series.
I first watched Fate/Stay night, then Fate/Zero and then Fate/Stay night UBW.The first season for me was kind of slow and at first when I watch the first episode I though it was the same as Fate/Stay night but I was wrong they are very different even though the end is pretty much the same but with a total different method and an amazing battle. In this one there is more character development than in Fate/SN, at least for Archer, Illya, Souchiro Kozuki, Lancer and even Berserker(Well maybe not that much) But they do have more participation and we get to know their motives.  This one feels also more related to Fate/Zero then Fate/SN as a sequel. As I said before the first season is kind of slow but there are some good moments like the battle with Caster, the interactions between Archer and Shirou and Kotomine Kirei that even though that guy is evil as F… he is a really good character at least to play as a decent villain. The second season starts with betrayal, surprises and good battles at this point I´going to admit that is NOT THE BEST ANIME EVER! To be honest I don´t think that such anime even exist because there are a lot of genders, stories and so on but UBW is REALLY GOOD. \n
So lets continue... I liked the art, the animation is very good, the battle scenes are very good as well. \n
The plot for me was good too. It surprises me in some episodes like Lancer´s behavior and Kotomine´s dead. I know that Saber did not have a lot of participation, lets say, but still one of the most important characters even though her relationship with Shirou was different that the one in Fate/SN.
