Anyone who sees this show should not compare it to Fate/Zero. UBW is not meant to be the sequel to Zero. UBW is part of the three routes of Fate/Stay Night along with Heaven's Feel and Fate. Zero is the prequel of Fate/Stay Night to explain the events of the VN. 
It's very hard to adapt a VN. Especially Fate, with 15+ hours a route. In order to adapt an anime, you lose a lot of Shirou's monologues and more detail of the story. A novel will always be better than the anime. Despite this, UBW is probably one of the best anime to comeof this year.


I have read the VN, and UBW is my favorite route. Not as light as Fate, not as dark as Heaven's Feel. It's a melancholy balance. The anime was put a bit in an awkward place. To truly understand it, you have to finish the Fate Route of the VN. However, UBW by itself is a ruby. Perhaps when the others come out it will become a pearl. 


The Characters are always the most important part of the VN. Shirou loses the most because his point of view is hard to depict, but he is an enjoyable protagonist who you can understand. Rin and Saber are the heroines with a past. They are fun, enjoyable, and make the anime fun. We have Archer, personally my favorite character in all anime, who is a realistic, cool, badass. Lancer, a champion with a heart of gold, gets a few episodes in the spotlight. Then we have Shinji, who we're supposed to hate, and Kotomine, a thoroughly enjoyable villain. The anime did very well to adapt intricate characters that we can thoroughly enjoy or despise. However, all the characters are interesting.


The music and art are obviously the center of this piece. They beat all the other anime. There truly is no comparison for the "Unlimited Budget Works." It makes the story much more enjoyable and a visual marvel for everyone.


The story is strong by itself, despite the setbacks of its awkward position (Needs a fate route to give a bit more info). The Holy Grail War is an interesting marvel, the clash of ideals regarding a "hero of justice", all of the story makes you both enticed and inquisitive. 


Truly, this is an enjoyable anime no matter what. It deserves a 10 from me and you guys too.

***This review may contain spoilers and has gone under the assumption you have previously finished Fate/zero.***
Lets start off by stating; Fate/stay night has some big shoes to fill. Its predecessor, Fate/zero, was a smashing hit and was well received by the anime community. Can the sequel to such a monumental anime live up to expectations? No, it couldn't, but it did do a lot right in its own regard.
Fate/stay night: Unlimited Blade Works is an anime adaptation, created by ufotable, of babies first visual novel... Sorry, Fate/stay night. The visual novel has three separate routes: the Fate route, the Unlimited Blade Works route and HeavensFeel route. This anime, as the title says, is the Unlimited Blade Works route, adapted into a 25 episode series.


Story - 6/10

The Holy Grail War is an age-old tradition that happens in Fuyuki city where seven Masters summon seven Servants. These Master Servant pairings must fight it out and eliminate one another until there is only one Master Servant pair left. Once there is only one pair left, the omnipotent wish granting device, the Holy Grail, reveals itself and grants one wish. The fifth Holy Grail War is the setting for Fate/stay night, and takes place ten years after the events of Fate/zero.


The premise sounds interesting and unique. The story can be riddled with surprising twists, unexpected alliances, betrayal, tactical warfare, and interesting relations between characters. The fear of knowing one could be killed at any moment sounds exhilarating. However, none of that really comes into play and instead we get a high school setting, with a bland main character, who has his own harem that he has to deal with. They story of Fate/stay night is unrealistic of the situation our characters find themselves in. The characters make stupid decision after stupid decision that can hardly be rationalized. The atmosphere feels far too care free given the circumstances. This is where Fate/stay night falls short compared to Fate/zero. The viewer doesn't get the same sense of urgency that Fate/zero offered, nor does it make the viewer feel as if the characters may die at any moment if they overstep their bounds. The pacing of the show is also incredibly slow and feels as if there is a lot of "filler" in each episode. Most of season one takes place at school, filled with characters have nothing to do with the grail war in the first place. The amount of time something just wasn't explained, or had an awful reasoning for an explanation is ludicrous. I know that Unlimited Blade Works was just one route of a possible three in the visual novel and that a lot of key elements might be distributed throughout all three routes, but come on, make it at least a bit of a better Anime viewing experience.


Overall, the premise of the story is interesting and continued off of what Fate/zero had going, but was executed poorly and riddled with missed opportunities.



Characters - 4/10

The characters of Fate/stay night can be summed up into one word: Unlikable. Forget the comparison to Fate/zero, which, by the way, had an incredible cast of characters; Fate/stay night has almost nothing going for it in terms of characters.

You can put make up on an ugly person, but at the end of the day, even though you made he/she look a little better for the time being, he/she is still ugly. That pretty much sums up three of the four main characters. Shiro, Rin, and Saber are so bad it's laughable. The show has it's brief periods of brilliance with adding depth and development to our main characters, but after the scene/episode, they go back to their same old self. The only character among the main group that doesn't completely suck is Archer, and even then he really wasn't that great. In terms of supporting cast the only characters that got any sort of spot light was Caster and Caster's master. Beyond that maybe Berserker, Ilya, Shinji and lancer... but at that point you're reaching. Everyone else is pretty much a write off with how little screen time they get and how little importance they have on the story itself and that includes the main villain, gilgamesh.

For a show that is so heavily focused on the adventures of Shiro and Rin, they sure dropped the ball. Unlimited Blade Works focused so hard on the main two characters that it cut time from other supporting characters and they couldn't even get the relationship for Shiro and Rin to work, let alone make them stand alone, likable characters.

I don't know if ufotable did an awful job adapting the characters from the visual novel, or if the visual novel itself just sucks, but something went horribly wrong...



Animations - 10/10

Finally, a shining light for this god forsaken anime.

Yes, ufotable does it again, creating a stunning looking anime. The animations quality was that of Fate/zero or even better. This might just be their best work yet. The motions were fluid and clean. Fight scenes, even the minor ones, were beautiful to watch. Everything, from the gorgeous fight scenes, right down to even basic scenes such as Rin and Shrio talking to each other looked great.

Overall fantastic animations quality. So good it should be reason enough to at least pick up and try the show out.



Sound - 8/10

The other shining light, the soundtrack.

The soundtrack, composed and created by Yuki Kajiura, was overall very well done and put together nicely. Each scene had a fitting piece to it and nothing felt out-of-place or awkward. The tracks themselves are also all incredible in their own right. Honestly, this was one of Yuki Kajiura weaker roles... but was still great none the less. The soundtrack did not live up to Fate/zero's soundtrack, but it definitely has more than a passable grade.

Both opening and endings we're great as well. Kalafina, Aimer and Mashiro Ayano all made awe-inspiring songs that set the mood perfectly for the start of the show and as a lasting impression after the episode.


Overall - Watching Fate/stay night as a "sequel" to Fate/zero is a mistake. It is a misleading title that has next to no "sequel" attributes to speak of. Watching Fate/stay night as a stand alone project that is not bogged down by the weight of Fate/zero is an actual good viewing experience. Fate/zero was a monumental, once in a life time Anime that Fate/stay night just could not live up to. Honestly, Fate/stay night is not even that bad of a show as a stand alone project. Just getting past the "sequel" part might be hard to wrap one's head around. If anything, watching Fate/stay night first, then going to Fate/zero would be a better viewing experience instead of the other way around.

The show, overall,  was a train wreck, but was thankfully salvaged by the all-star line up of ufotable and Yuki Kajiura. It had its moments of brilliance but squandered the moments the show itself created. Unlimited Blade Works was incredibly hit or miss, it's just too bad it was more miss than hit.

Spoilers: For me Anime is not the only thing I do, watch, and is interested in. So when I watch an Anime to completion it has to have caught my attention. The Fate/Zero series I saw on Netflix couple of year ago an really enjoyed it and when I saw that Unlimited Blade Works had been released I had to watch it as well. Overall I enjoyed the series. I feel that this season, however, felt a little dragged on compared to season 1. Maybe because in Fate/Zero we were watching more than one story unfold compared to just following Shirō & Rin around &season 1 of UBW felt decently fast paced. A good example of this was Kirei just showing up in episode 20. I would have liked to have more insight on his and Gilgamesh's interactions.  I also didn't like the whole Shirō & Rin romance for the fact they seem to just walk this line of awkward the entire time. I'm not a guy into cushy lovey dovey stuff, but I would have rather had some progression. Even at the end I wasn't sure if they were together or in some just weird awkward friendship. I don't know, it just bugged me. Also where were Sakura & Taiga all season? Tropical island drinking coconuts? Who knows? Oh, & the memory of I assume Shirō doing back flips...they bring it up once & discard it immediately. Made no sense to me. And my final complaint was Waver. Him & Rider were my favorite characters from Fate/Zero, but the way they do it is just odd. I had to google just to make sure it was him like I thought. All in all, while I have my complaints its still a great watch. The action scenes look great and the dialogue was always superb. If you liked Animes like Sword Art Online, Attack on Titan, or The Future Diary(Mirai Nikki) I think you will enjoy it.

Story: 8/10- The story of Fate/Stay is interesting, the Holy Grail War always has been always will be. At times it was confusing, but the overall story telling and plot with delivered greatly. With astonishing closure to the series, it is one of my favorites 
Art: 10/10- What is there to say? Ufotable did an amazing job with Fate/Stay just as in Fate/Zero, it's beautiful and the fight scenes are beautifully animated. The fight scenes are so fluid that it feels as if your eyes were blessed by the gods that are Ufotable 
Sound: 10/10- My ears were blessed for 13 episodes straight.
Characters: 8/10- Withoutany spoilers I can say the main characters Rin,Shirou, and Saber are really the only one that get any development, but that can't really be helped due to the enormous cast that is introduced (Then possibly killed of later), but overall I thought most of the character's were very respectable, they're heroes after all. \n\n
Enjoyment: 10/10- My eyes were glued on the screen the entire season. You can't really go wrong with watching it. I had a lot of fun of watching it, and it's something I suggest you watch. \n\n
Overall:- 9/10- Fate/Stay night is one a great series, it has flaws in some regards to its story and progression, but the pros heavily outweigh the cons to watching this anime.

"His body was made of swords, his blood was made of iron, his heart was made of glass
 he conquered many battlefields
 not even retreating once
 not even being understood once
 he stays on the top of an hill made of swords
 thus, his life holds no meaning"
IMPORTANT: If you never watched Fate: Zero or you have never played the original VN (like myself) I deeply recommend you to gain additional informations about the lore of the series (avoiding spoilers) because otherwise, you will find some difficulties in understanding some points of this anime. I had to do this and for this reasons I wrotethis introductive note



I usually realize from the very first episodes of a series if I'm watching an awful work, a good enteraining story or a true masterpiece. And I wasn't wrong with Fate: Stay Night Unlimited Blade works. The review will cover the second half of the season: I would have liked to review it in his whole 24 episodes run, but the site don't permit it, so...


Story - 10

Yes. I give it a solid 10 and many people will be disappointed by this. Because the VN was better, because Fate Zero or Fate Stay Night 2006 were better and such. I never saw the older series and I never played the game, I only investigated some plot points after finishing UBW because some things weren't clear. 

In my opinion, the story is perfect. Just like that. Initially, especially in the first series, some points bugged me. I will not spoil plot details there, however, because in my opinion, if you decide to watch this anime, you don't really want spoilers

The second half of the first arc left me disappointed. Filler episodes, a slow pacing, anticlimactic things (such as battles that are stopped for no reasons)

Well, from the very first episode of the second arc, I understood that things were changing. There are two main revelations or plot twists that hit me like a punch in the jaw. Really, I am not a person who gets surprised or excited by plot twists, but, wow...


MASSIVE SPOILER ALERT!!!!

The first. Archer's betrayal. That make a lot of sense when you discover...


...that his goal is to kill Emyia Shirou because HE IS Emyia Shirou from the future! Since servants came both from the past and the future. Holy shit, the first thing left me speechless and was totally unexpected but also coherent with the story. Because Archer's willingness to work for Rin was motivated by his desire to kill Shirou in the war. This is the reason why he wants so much to attack him in the first arc. And when he understands that Rin is in love with him and will never turns his weapons against him, well, Archer leaves the crew. I don't understand why he didn't killed him on the spot: probably, he decided to destroy his beliefs, first.

And the fact that Archer was Shirou. Maybe I was naive but I didn't suspected it for a single moment until the revelation. Mainly because, having never played the VN, I was convinced that servants are only heroes from the real world. I didn't knew that a character of the series could become a Counter Guardian 

From the first episode of the second arc, the story goes on fluidly. A minor issue was the fact that there are too much dialogues, maybe, and some of them are repetitive. But this thing doesn't take any merit from a beautiful story. 

The ending is probably one of the best final that I ever seen in an anime. In the end, Shirou is unable to change himself. Changing his ideals is either impossible or would make his life meaningless. And so, he will go on on his path, even knowing that it will lead him to his damnation. Even thought that he will suffer and lose everything and everyone, including his ideals. I found this thing dramatically realistic. Think about how many people every day take paths that will lead them to their demise, even suspecting or knowing what will happen. Because men are like that: they are more eager to die than to change themselves. This is the main reason of unhappiness and suffering in the world. 

Rin Toosaka can only promise to be with him and love him. She says: "It doesn't matter what will happen to you after. It matters where you will get" then, we have a panoramic of the sunset and the night on London, with the camera that zooms out from their window, that gives the idea of ​​a life that continues to move forward, regardless of what will be tomorrow. And the final monologue of Archer/Shirou: "He will regret and curse the path that he has chosen. But in the end, I was never wrong"

The message is strong: the world is not fair, the world doesn't give a fuck about you and you are the only one responsible for your happiness so, if you chose to follow your path, you and only you will face for the consequences. Doing what is right is not equal to doing what is convenient. Idealists are condemned to unhappiness. However, ideals are not wrong. They make us what we truly are. This is the paradox and the eternal struggle between what we feel right and what we must do to go on. 

Powerful. Great. 


SPOILERS END THERE FOR NOW - GO ON SAFELY 


I reassume fo the ones who don't want spoilers: the reasons why I gave 10 to the story of UBW are mainly two: great plot twists and strong and realistic messages that will leave you with a lot of questions. Personally, I loved every other aspects of the story but those two points really stand out. 


Art -9

As I read in some memes, "Unlimited Budget Works!" 

True. When you have great funds, you will have great action scenes, breathtaking landscapes (Archer's singularity space is beautiful and reflects perfectly his moral and his past life), well drawn characters and no drops in quality towards the end. There is more to say? 

For action fans, the battles and the fights are great. Amongst the best I have ever seen. 

The setting is beautiful. A blessing fo your eyes.


Sound -9

The OST features some great tracks such as Ring your bell, This Illusion, EMYIA and, on the top of everything, Brave Shine, that is one of the best openings even heard in an anime (I put it I my playlist even before watching the series)

The sound effects were also great and the Italian dub is very good, as usually


Character-8

Some characters are deeply characterized, some are less explored. Some monologues are a bit exaggerated and sound like boasts, others are powerful and give a perfect reflection of the motives of the characters

However, a thing that I loved is the fact that the majority of the characters are interesting. Almost nobody feels out of place or wasted during his screen time, I even appreciated some characters who appeared in a couple of scenes only 

I will take the main characters as examples, just to give you an idea

Emyia Shirou is an idealist. In the first arc, I wasn't very fond of him: I thought in multiple occasions that is behavior was stupid and makes no sense in some parts. He is obsessed by the thought of saving everybody, even at the cost of his own life. Then, in the second arc, you understand. He is not mentally stable. The fire that almost killed him in his first ages of life, the fact that his stepfather talked about "being an hero"... those things greatly influences a kid...

Hence, my interpretation: he suffers from mental issues. For this reason, he is unable to change. Is realistic and is haunting, is the kind of thing that I like to see in a series because is something that happens in everyday life too (expect for the part with the magic and the hope of becoming a Counter Guardian, unfortunately) 

The only spark of hope for his fate is Rin Toosaka

I saw a lot of "meh" love relationships in anime but I actually liked the couple Rin-Shirou. Their love is not just "for the plot and the ship", it grows more and more strong ad they fight together and risk their lives in a magic Battle Royale where the odds are against them. The fact that a possible sex scene was dropped for a weird sequence with dolphins (yeah, you read it right) was a bit disappointing because that would have been the turning point of their relationship and it would have made sense since they both knew that they could actually be dead the very next day, but I'm satisfied enough by the fact that their couple become official in the ending

Rin Toosaka is also an interesting character. She takes part in the Graal War to "Win it and nothing more" but, as the story goes on, we can speculate that the does this to avenge his father, who died in the last one. She is smart and she wants so be ruthless but when Shirou is involved in the war, her determination falters. She is not able to be merciless as she wants to be and her feelings come to surface as time goes on. 


GUESS WHAT? SPOILERS


Archer. Another great character. His behavior in the first arc is totally justified when we discover that HE IS Shirou and his objective is to kill him to stop existing in the first place. His extreme idealism has lead him to the worst possible outcome, an eternal life that he has to spend killing people for the sake of "peace" and the safety of humanity as we know it. I tought that he only wanted to win the Graal war but I was wrong. He is another realistic character: an idealist who is not able to see the harsh reality of the world will often become a nihilist with no faith in humanity or in life, just like him. I felt very connected to him


SPOILERS ENDS HERE FOR NOW


A minor disappointment: I felt that Saber is put in the shadows. She deserved a better introspection. Her backstory is not explored much and she is kept a bit off the spotlights and is a shame because she is one of the most iconic characters of the franchise (her backstory is explored mainly in Fate Zero and in the VN


Enjoyment -9

If the first arc bored me a bit in his second half, the second arc was amazing. I can't find a single episode that is not entertaining or that feels wasted. Plot twists, great battles between overpowered characters realized with awesome special effects, deep scenes that explore the psychology and the motives of the characters, an interesting depiction of mature themes such as the meaning of ideals, the struggle between what is right and what is convenient, the clash between our desire to act kind and with justice and the ruthless reality of a selfish and violent world that consumes the main character. I didn't expected to find such a maturity in an anime that don't looks exactly aimed to a mature audience from his cover



What else I can say, Fate Stay Night: Unlimited Blade Works was a nice surprise. I expected a good series since this anime is very popular and, as I said, I thought that it could be a masterpiece from the very first episode. His reputation is deserved and I recommend it. Guaranteed, some parts are a bit repetitive and over boasted, some monologues are a bit exaggerated but that's not a major issue. The story is great and you will easily grow fond of the characters. 

I'm talking as an occasional anime watcher and I never played the VN (I'm searching it on amazon, however, I have to play it absolutely) so maybe if you are a fan of the original story you may be disappointed by some things that I flat out ignored, however, if you never heard anything about the Fate series, you will be dragged in this world easily by this awesome product.

I don't know how helpful this will be since i have so many thoughts jumbled around in my head after just finishing the UBW series so bare with me. Or don't. 
I don't think I have ever come across such a series that I had such conflicting views about, while still enjoying the entire season of UBW(This review is for both seasons). Also, I will be comparing this to the previous fate:zero & not at all with fate stay night, since everyone knows that's shit. 
For starters, let's just get the good out of the way, the good that we can't argue about. Fight scenesare amazing and animated great, as is the animation all around. These things are expected after fate:zero and UBW delivers. As for sound, it fits the series well, though I cannot say I enjoy the openings or endings for any fate series, including this one but the soundtrack is pleasant and memorable to a degree and it certainly fits the show well. 


Big fucking problems begin when it comes to characters. This is where my rant begins. 


The biggest problems people seem to have is that our boy Emiya, the classic shounen dummy, is well, a classic shounen dummy. Not powerful, but has the will do it all. & so on & so on. His views are recycled through anime, and he's pretty annoying. That's all true & his ideals can be a bit repetitive and unoriginal, not at all like my nigga kiritsugu from fate zero. But i don't have a problem with him. It's so recycled that i know what to expect & so you can either bitch about him or just accept him like I did. He wasn't unbearable and  though I can't say he changes too much, as far as mentality(because that's the whole point; sticking to his beliefs) he was an okay character. Rin, the female protag, can be seen as almost just as annoying with opposite yet just as recycled ideals, though unlike emiya, she develops some change but just barely . That's all fine and good. There are even characters that you think are going to be important, and they might have been in the VN, but in UBW? they disappear early on and you never hear from them again, despite scenes where those characters are clearly involved. I can't really say anything for spoiler's sake but you'll know when you see them. 


MY biggest problem is the supporting characters. Nearly all are from the same school(a stupid coincidence) & none of them are particularly interesting.. Shinji is like a shit version of that serial killer guy from fate:zero, & illyasaviel is a huge let down, especially as in fate zero her mother had such a huge role with a personality and her role in the story barely serves a purpose, despite being let up from the beginning to be some kind of powerful badass. The truth is, she is boring and turns out to be a garbage character. Then there's the robotic like teacher, who I can't remember his name because that's how boring his character is. He was actually important yet so boring and thus, not memorable. Then there's kirei who was like a huge antagonist(if not THE antagonist) in fate zero with a personality and background. Here, he is little shown, still an asshole, and when he is shown during the end, is a huge let down in the story. A huge let down actually describes this whole show. 


All, and I mean all, the servants were fucking stupid or way less cool. Saber went from being a cool badass with ideals, conflicts & a real personality, as well as character development to a boring cliche ecchi version of herself. Pretty sure emiya thought about fucking her several times as the animators got his face all red everytime she & him talked. They could be talking about soap and next thing you know, emiya's got a hard on for her. Archer(fate zero archer,  gilgamesh) went from being a cool character with an interesting belief system, as well as being a cool villain, to being just a villain. He was an asshole completely & his schemes were stupid & he seemed like a less smart version of himself before. The berserk class was way less interesting than before, served little narrative, and barely had a real impact on the story, unlike the previous one did in fate zero. Lancer class; same story. Less interesting, no background or ideals, or real personality and served no purpose. Assassin? I still don't even get that whole story but it makes sense I don't, since the show never really gave him one. He's an even bigger waste of a character than assassin from the fate zero series but unlike that one, he serves less of a purpose and seems like he was only there to get in people's way at the writer's convenience. Caster character was, for some reason, made up to be such a big deal throughout the show, and in truth, was a big antagonist, but it's like, who the fuck was the chick in real life? never heard of her, & as a servant I never liked her. She had no real ideals or personality, other than that she was a bitch and for some reason, fucking hounded the protags for like 18 episodes or some shit. Then there was the rider character. Holy fuck. She had like 4 lines, one fight scene, and I don't even think they gave her a background, let alone revealed her actual name. Archer was the only servant who had any background, ideals, personality, etc & the reason for that, which I can't say, makes sense given the ending and truths that are revealed but because of that, is a huge copout. 


The story itself was terribly paced, random and lacked a linear plot that even remotely made sense. Shit was way too rushed, not so much in the sense that they didn't have enough time, but rather that the writers made that time way too fast. Plots were happening at rates that didn't even make any sense and one minute something is important & the next it isn't. The result? A subpar ending. 


Fuck, my thoughts are jumbled on this one. 


At least in every episode, something happened. Like there was no wasted moments, and there was lots of action to keep you entertained. Honestly, this shit should be ranked in the 200's but whatever, 96 will have to do. I would suggest watching this, it's fair to good, but if you really want to enjoy this series without a bad taste in your mouth, watch this, then watch fate zero & you will have no bad taste. This sequel is terrible in comparison. 


TL;DR version


Great action scenes with great animation and quality sound. Plot is rushed, messy and as a result, develops into a poorly treated story, saved only by your desire to finish the fate series and see what happens. The characters are terrible in comparison to fate zero, especially the servants, and as stand alone, they are poor, often given no background, a unique personality/ideals & can often seem recycled and bland, and a result, boring and unlikable. 


Just to finish after my probable unhelpful rant, this show's characters are it's worst attribute and it's story nearly just as bad. No matter what your entertainment value is, was, or will be, if you do not want to be disappointed,  I want to say do not watch this(assuming you have seen fate zero). But, if you wanted to find out how it ended like me, or if you heard good things like me, just give it a try. Reviews shouldn't be the thing that lets you watch something or not. Decide on your own why you didn't like the show. Reviews are pretty useless but I wanted to talk about the show, even if it's just for my own benefit. So, if you got any help from this rant, good. If not, do try and watch the show. 


Or don't. squad.

okay, First of all, YES I did read the visual novel, no I didn't understand it right away the first time I watched it but the thing with the fate series is that it is much like kingdom hearts or monogatari in that it will always have more to explore.
what is shown is always just the tip of the ice burg. why is that ??? some might ask arrogantly acting like they are entitled to know of a world with immersive depth that is incomprehensible to the average seasonal anime watcher. 
this show deal's with Magic. ever since J.K Rowlings Harry Potter series we haveseen the subject of magic be approached like it is some mathematical formula like it is something easily comprehensible to the layman.  this is fundamentally different from fate's interpretation of magic. 


Yes magic is taught from family to eldest born, but it is not seen as normal even by its users there is reverence for magecraft something I don't really see in say the likes of harry potter


"facts don't care about your feelings" has become fetishized to the point that some groups of people (Ie Reddit). want to associate themselves with always logical and rational at all times discrediting anything contrary to this world view this obsessive rationality is in a way a form of OCD. 


so they avoid anything with "superstitious" or "emotional" components as this might make them look less "rational" 


Religion, Astrology, the Arts and yes even some medical scientific disciplines namely Psychology aren't always based on 100 % logic.


I blame the Harry Potter series for the most part for this as its something that takes the nature of witchcraft magic and a whole myriad of fantastical ideas. reinterprets it in a very western bourgeoisie fashion and says see z = X+ Y for spells it rationalizes magic in the way in the same manner a chemist goes about creating a chemical reaction. 


magic is NOT supposed to make sense you ARENT supposed to KNOW EVERYTHING all the time that's part of being in the Nasu verse. 


id talk about the story but I'm presuming you've already made up your mind with this series either you love it or you hate it. I like it I feel like

(this is a review of both season1 and season 2 in one bundle)
After watching Fate/Zero, I had high expectations for Fate/Stay night. (yes i know the order sucks...) but upon finishing the mediocre fate/Stay night by deen, I was feeling a bit... unsatisfied. And also reluctant to start Fate/Stay night UBW (henceforth F/SNUBW) because it looked like a better animated rerun. But boy was I wrong...also i haven't read the VNs so keep that in mind if that happens to be important.
Story:9
Best part of the story is it's unpredictability. It had alot of twists and turns, a lot of tension and suspense derived from that.The premise of the story is basically the same as Fate/Zero, but how it played out was much more intense. And that was what really placed it at a 10 for me, it was it's intensity and unpredictability. There is one qualm i have though, and that would be the plot device of the "rule breaker". not to spoil too much, but it basically allows one of the characters to skirt the rules. Which makes total nonsense because it basically defeats the purpose of the damn grail war. But anyways, story-wise it works well both alone, and in conjunction with fate/Zero


Art:10

HOLY CRAP. the jokes about UBW standing for "unlimited budget works" was not a joke. this anime has one of the best animations, art, and fluidity i have ever seen. it makes every other 10 i've given for art meaningless. Lets go first art and design. its amazing. period. no half-assing anywhere. every shot, every scene is consistent with the last. there is no cutting corners here. The art is literally the most life-like art ever. Secondly, animation. Its also top notch. characters move fluidly, they fit with the scenery, nothing is choppy or jerky. again the word here is "lifelike". And i had to add this, but background details. The attention to detail is freaking amazing. even small things like people fighting in rain, snow, or animation of clouds going across a sky are all extremely well done and its clear to see that the production group gave 110%. No joke. it's insane. 


Sound:9

Not a big fan of OP/ED songs, or the sort of person who pays attention to background music. its alright. nothing amazing. nothing subpar either. it's just a very solid music score. It didn't make me notice it, so not very fond of it. The song's didn't make me want to listen to them again, nor did the in anime music catch my attention. 


Character:8

Would have given it a 7 just because of how idiotic Shirou is, but felt that that would be biased. Anyways, Character-wise it was decent. There is alot of development, and none of the main characters are flat. Seriously not bad. But I gave it an 8, why? well two things. Shirou and Shinji. literally the worst characters ever. Shirou's always getting in the way of his own goals for 75% of the story, and Shinji is just a sore loser cunt. Shirou goes through character development which is his only redeeming quality, but still... why spend so much time doing that?


Enjoyment:10

Despite the weak characters, I enjoyed this anime immensely. it was such a welcome change to the mediocre F/SN. It had an amazing story, stunning art, and really those two things were conducive to my enjoyment. Also it was a fitting end to F/Zero. It didn't have my favorite category (ecchi), nor was it uncensored, but it was still enjoyable for it's intense battle scenes, good story. etc.


OVERALL: 9

It really is an amazing anime. Story-wise it was intense.  It had the "wow" factor just as much as it had the "oh sh*t went down" vibe. it was dark, dystopian, but also mysterious, a real journey filled with enjoyable plot. Art was above anything I've ever seen. Superior to any anime in all aspects. again it rewrites what i thought was possible for anime artistically. Characters were all very cool, not bad, though some had grating personalities. And thats where the one point comes of overall. its just the characters. They're great, and fit with the story, but theyre just not a personal favorite. So in short, id say 3 for story +4 for Art + 2 for enjoyment = 9 overall


Peace

While i liked the first half the season but then the second half starts and i am very conflicted towards it. Instead of talking about the animation and soundeffects i want to talk more about the problems that i see in the second half.
Problem 1: Visual novel sickness
Unlimited blade works is the second route in the Fate Stay Night visual novel and therefore it is clear that some characters does not get any screentime while others get plenty of it. The transition from the novel to the anime is a painful one, Saber for example is such victim. If you came from FateZero and neverread the novel you will see the difference where she is standing in the background but if you have read the novel you know why. 


Shirou and Archer gets plenty of time since this is their route while Rin gets to be the helpless girl in the second half of the show and does not contribute too much. Therefore the anime on its own cannot stand on its two legs if you are watching this without any knoledge about the novel itself.


Problem 2: heavy dialogue 


In the second half the dialogue is very heavy, dialogue between Archer and Shirou is a pure example. Episode 19 och 20 is almost delicated to the dialogue where Shirou and Archer exchanges their point of view when it comes to justice and ideals. The problem with this is that it is not very complex dialogue but it is dragged out for no reason and it slows the action down, something that Ufotable is known for. Almost every episode feels like a drag when it comes to dialogue. This is holy grail war not some talkshow about ideals. Sure, FateZero had also this kind of dialogue between Saber and Kiritsugu but it felt more integrated within the context and it did not take up the entire episode.


Conclusion:


Dialogue heavy second half slows the show down and also contributes to its pacing issues. Battles are great when they take place but you need patience until then. I can understand both Shirou and Archers motives but if you repeat them several times over and over again then it becomes dull and somewhat stupid.


Second half is worth watch but be warned that you need some patience to finish it.

This is a review for both the first and this second season of Fate/Stay Night: Unlimited Blade Works. First fo all, I have to say that I watch the STUDIO DEEN version of Fate/Stay Night, which was based on the FATE route of the visual novel of the same name. I have also watched the anime movie UNLIMITED BLADE WORKS, so my praise for this anime will be influenced a bit having seen those versions of it before watching this. (Note: that I also watched Fate/Zero before this too, but it won't have any particular influence over it.)
Story: 10/10
Every since the highly spoken of disasterthat was STUDIO DEEN's Fate/Stay Night adaptation, I've been obsessed with the idea of this story. So much potential, a beautiful idea in my opinion. Having seen STUDIO DEEN's version first, I didn't think it was bad at all, in fact I gave it an 8 overall. BUt this ufotable 2nd route adaptation fo the visual novel gave me everything I wanted for such a story that I had become to love the idea of. It did excellent in all the criteria given for me to rate this by and I will elaborate more about it in each. As for the story, as I said, it gave me exactly what I wanted.


Art: 10/10


It's quite obvious that the art is spectacular. One does not simply watch this anime in low-ass quality video played on the internet, you need blu-ray quality!!! LOL beautiful art, sceneic, almost realistic settings, the lighting in each scene perfectly reflects the mood of night and day, of light and shadow.


Sound: 10/10


Intense, sad, reflected, sinister and more when it is needed to be so at the right moments.


Character: 10/10


What I love the most about this one is the character development. It is possible that if I hadn't seen STUDIO DEEN's creations I might have known less about the characters, such as the RIDER of this war, but I feel they touched on areas that were never touched on in STUDIO DEEN's version, but that's perhaps due to the fact that this is a different route than the other. The delved into the back stories of many characters, both master AND servants. I really appreciated that.


Enjoyment 10/10


Duh! Plus I had been waiting for this for quite a long time. It met my expectations too. I love it!


Overall: 10/10 HELL YEAH!

This Anime features an AMAZINGLY beautiful animation and bright, vibrant colours which emphasise certain details. This is commonly used on someone’s weapon during a battle to help the viewer better keep track of an AMAZINGLY beautiful fight scene. Which is the next point, amazing fight scenes. Each fight scene is beautifully crafted and all are equally purposeful.
The story is very well done, with each episode ending perfectly, some episodes even follow a lengthened form of approximately 47 minutes vs the normal 23 minute length. The story perfectly captures character and relationship development throughout the Anime. The Animealso delves into each character’s unique and compelling back story, the Anime shows both back stories of main, sub, characters that both live and die. Allowing every viewer to develop an emotional connection with each and every character including the servants themselves.


Not only the characters but their interactions feel fully fleshed out and for the most part organic and true to the personalty of each character.


Finally to the end of the Anime. The ending is a satisfying yet open ended finish to the Anime. It both left it open to sequels and left the viewer feeling resolution of the story.


With every masterpiece there are small hiccups, which disqualify them from being a prefect masterpiece. With this Anime, however there was little to be picky about. Although there were a few characters which needed more attention and fleshing out. All in all a true masterpiece and a MUST WATCH for anyone wanting an amazing action filled Anime that boasts the highest quality. This Anime deserves my rating score of 10: Epic Masterpiece.

(Here is a review for both seasons because the show does not deserve the time taken for two reviews.)
My previous experience with Fate is with Fate/Zero only. Take that however you want. 
Fate/Stay Night: Unlimited Blade Works came out of the gate with an extremely strong first 2 episodes. The artistic direction and timing was promising a very cool perspective based death gamethat showed multiple angles of the same events from different characters perspectives. However after those first 2 special long episodes the series walks away form that angle completely.\n\n
The visuals were quite impressive at times with some nice environments and pretty good fighting shots. The show was riddled with terrible CG liquid and fire that really contrasted poorly against the 2d portions of the same scene. \n\n
The soundtrack felt very generic and if I have to hear a stock frying pan/sheers cutting sound one more time I may go insane. First seasons OP was good though.\n\n
The gripes I had with the characterization and narration of Fate/Zero were only amplified here with the absence of Emiya Kiritsugu. Characters were fairly flat and one-note and the dialogue absolutely drowned out all the fun the fight scenes were providing me. The Caster class Heroic Spirit and Master were actually interestingly characterized and made me seriously question how they were dealt with by our protagonists. \n\n
I don't know if this sort of anime just doesn't appeal to me or if this anime was genuinely bad with constant use of Deus Ex Machina, Narration that doesn't actually explain anything, and monologues about ideals that are so backwards in logic that I had to legitimately wonder if the translation team wasn't fundamentally screwing something up or just playing a prank on me.\n\n
I didn't like it, but something about Fate wants me to watch more of it's other properties. Does that mean it's doing something right? I honestly don't know.

Production and Popularity
The second season continues the story of Fate/Stay Night: Unlimited Blade works, based on the 2010 movie of the same name and the 2006 Fate/Stay Night series. These were all based on the original FSN Visual novel by Type Moon. The animation studio was again Ufotable. Compared to the first season, which was rated 8.41 by 175 thousand voters, the second season is even more overwhelmingly popular, 8.71 by 230 thousand voters. Although relatively few people bothered to rate FSN:UBW on IMDb or Crunchyroll, the average is still 8.1 out of 10, and 4.5 stars out of 5, respectively. Genres and themes includeaction, fantasy, supernatural, thriller, psychological, personal value systems, loyalty, friendship, and battle royale.  


Story Structure


As usual in my reviews, I want to note the story composition used, as someone interested in the structure of good storytelling in media. The plot can be interpreted several ways. If the story of the Holy Grail War, the action, is thought of as the central plot, the structure is as follows. Major plot points are the fight with Caster in episode 1, seeing the fate of Illya in episode 3, defeating Caster in episode 5, Archer's past, fighting Archer, and Archer's fate in episodes 7-9, and the final battle stretched over episodes 11 and 12. Season one used a 1-3-6-8-10-12 plot point format, and season two is similar if you think of it as 1-3-5-7-9-12. A lot of things happens from 6 to 9 that are part of the same "Arc" of the revealing of Archer's past, his intentions, and his fight with Shirou. That accounts for the slight difference in story structure. 


The plot can also be thought of as the story of Shirou's personal journey. That journey had three parts in season one and four parts in season two. The climaxes for Shirou are confessing to Rin in episode 1, having his ideals challenged by Rin in episode 4, reaffirming his ideals in the fight with Archer by episode 8 or 9, and becoming a hero and survivor of the Holy Grail War in episode 12. This 1-4-9-12 structure is excellently designed for showing the progress of Shirou's character. The epilogue, episode 13, is also important, as it discusses his future with Rin. Later on, I will discuss Shirou's personal journey in more detail. My only complaints about the story were a) that it was somewhat predictable, and b) that it echoed anime where characters had similar journeys as Shirou, such Sayaka in Madoka Magica and Akane in Psycho-Pass.


Art Overall 


Please see my review of the first season for more detail on my thoughts of the art. As with season one, FSN:UBW delivers a high-quality experience for the senses. It's beautiful and colorful. The animation of the fight scenes is excellent, though I personally would have liked to see some more realistic, rather than explosive and fantastical, battles. The character designs are unforgettable, but it seems to me that more thought is put into the colors and powers of the characters than to their individual expressions. The range of expression is somewhat limited.  


Sound: Acting, Songs, and OST


FSN:UBW features the voices of Kana Ueda as Rin, Noriaki Sugiyama as Shirou, and Junichi Suwabe as Archer, among others. The performances were more than satisfactory, though nothing truly unforgettable. Please see my review of the first season of FSN:UBW for more information on the seiyuu. The popular voice actor Hiroshi Kamiya makes a minor appearance as Shinji Matou. Even with such a small role, he does an impressive job.


Once again, the soundtrack was memorable. Opening theme "Brave Shine" by Aimer is even better than season one's opening in my opinion. Aimer has since become known in the anime industry for performing various other songs, such as the ED for Zankyou no Terror, Koutetsujou Kabaneri, and one of the many ending songs in Bleach. Ending theme "Ring your Bell" by Yuki Kajiura was just as great. Ms. Kajiura is a singer/song-writer who has performed music in anime such as Pandora Hearts, Madoka Magica, Fate/Zero, and Boku Dake ga Inai Machi ("Erased"). "Ring your Bell is an upbeat and inspiring song.  


The OST for FSN:UWB 2nd Season was again composed by Hideyuki Fukasawa. The 24 tracks in the OST II are beautiful. A few of them seem to lack originality, but all of them are high quality nonetheless. Memorable tracks include "Illyasviel von Einzbern," a pretty and somewhat creepy melody, "Ideal/Betrayal," and "This Illusion," used for discussions and flashbacks of Archer's past, "Excalibur," an epic, thematic score, and "Emiya UBW," the exciting, upbeat, yet emotional theme for Shirou once he has come to terms with his conflicts.  While I watched the actual anime, very few of these stuck out of me, but whenever I listen to the OST II, I am always impressed. (A short piece that I did notice while watching was "Fictional Heroic Spirit," used for the Assassin character who guards Caster's temple.)


Characters Overall


Virtually FSN:UBW characters are memorable, and in the second season, some of the one-dimensional ones receive their much-needed attention. And example is Caster, who didn't have much of a personality in the first season, but who showed her true values and intentions (largely through flashbacks) in the second installment. Some characters where expanded on, but not enough, such as Saber (I wanted to know more about her thoughts and personal journey) and Assassin (I would have liked at least half an episode about him). Once again, Saber's outstanding morality and chivalry make her admirable to lovers of classic heroes, while rough and rugged Archer gives fans a more human hero with a dark side. Archer gets a lot of development in the second season and I think the series did a great job with him. 


As with the first season, I believe Rin and Shirou are rare and much-needed types of protagonists in anime. Shirou represents the selfless yet deeply flawed hero-to-be, and Rin is a breath of fresh air as a strong, talented, and outspoken female hero. For more detail on these characters, please see my review of FSN:UBW Season One.


Enjoyment and Notes on Shirou's Story


My enjoyment of FSN:UBW 2nd Season was higher than what I experienced in the first season, which is why I rated the first season 7 (good) and the second season 8 (very good). I found some events predictable, and I thought that other things weren't made clear enough. I was also disappointed not to see more about Saber's personal journey, and to be honest I wanted a little more romance between Shirou and Rin. There was much less discussion of the truth of what the Holy Grail really is, and the ending for the over-powered villain seemed a little too convenient. The thing I enjoyed most about the series was the story of Shirou’s personal journey, which is discussed below. (As spoiler-free as possible.) 


Among vocal fans on crunchyroll and gogoanime, Shirou is far from being the most well-liked character. Complaints about him are that he is too soft-hearted, that his stubbornness makes him stupid, and that he is too much of a dreamy idealist. Though it may not be the fan favorite, I believe it is meaningful to have heroes like this (every now and then) in anime, because whether they admit it or not, many people have been through the same mental stages as Shirou. If Shirou was annoying to me, it's because he reminded me too much of myself. I'll bet I'm not the only one who thinks this. 


His is a classic story. Without much else to base his unsteady identity on, Shirou devotes himself to his values, which are idealistic and not really feasible in the real world, and which tend to break a person in the end. He wishes to save everybody even at the expense of himself and his soul. While Shirou is the idealistic child, Archer is like the disillusioned adult, and that's why he is more popular. Nobody likes to remember how stupid they were when thought like Shirou. We prefer to think of ourselves as Archers, stuck in an unfair system, and betrayed by our values until we become skeptical, regret-filled, and emotionally distant characters. For some people, the journey ends there. And in indeed, even in the series, we are certainly not guaranteed a happy future for Archer. But note the significance of the conclusion Shirou draws in his fight with Archer. 


Shirou acknowledged that most of what Archer said was true. However, the thing that re-inspired him to keep going with values was the memory that he has known all along he would be walking into a living hell. From early childhood, Shirou walks through figurative hell, fully knowing what it is, and still looking for people to save. Archer simply forgot that he had committed to such a fate from the beginning; he got caught up in the hypocrisy of having to kill people to save other people. Shirou was made aware of the "save many at the cost of the few" problem, and he decides to continue regardless. "Even if that life is that of a machine," he says, "even if that life is dripping with hypocrisy, I'll keep striving to be Seigi no Mikata (ally/hero of justice)." 


Very few people have the determination to stick to their values even knowing that it will result in intense, possibly lifelong, suffering. This is what makes Shirou an incredible person. Certainly, there are those who simply consider him foolish, and I think so myself sometimes, but anyone who once swore themselves to their values will see the honor and courage in trying to stick to those values regardless of the outcome.

This is a review from someone who DID NOT read the visual novel, and watched Fate/Stay Night, Fate/Zero and Unlimited Blade Works in this order.
At 1st, I imagine this would be just like Fate/Stay Night with a Rin route, but it turns out completely different from the 2006 anime. Aside from episode 1, its a totally different story. I still recommend watching it so you can get a better understanding of the whole story. And please, watch Fate/Zero before watching UBW.
I could say the initial catch about this show is the animation. Its basically top notch, its so good that makes you wonder how muchmoney was put into it. Fights are fantastic, the effects of lightning and shadows are perfect, the characters look awesome. Its unfair to compare UBW and SN, it would only be fair with Zero, and its still a lot superior.\n\n
Now, the show has 2 problems: pacing and wasted romantic potential. About pacing, you have incredible "fast" episodes where a lot of stuff happens and it seems rushed, while others are a lot slower. And about romance, its always implied that they love each other and eventually have a serious relationship, but again, its ONLY IMPLIED. I don't know about you, but that utherly pisses me off. In every romance story, you watch the whole thing waiting for that one special moment, and when it never happens, I feel like I was fooled the entire time.\n
Also on this subject, Shirou feels like an emotionless doll all the time. Even he says that he likes he, his expression doesnt demonstrate that it all. Aside from helping and saving her, he does nothing to express his feelings, what makes his "love" sound weird and superficial. Rin is way more expressive.\n\n
You have fantastic animation and fighting scenes, a whole new approach to the Fate world and Shirou turns out pretty badass in the end, almost redeeming himself from being an loveless doll. Sadly, I regret that some characters were forgotten midway through the show. Overall, a very entertaining show. Just a few changes from being perfect.

Let me sing my praises to UFOTABLE - for managing to perfectly adapt the Fate/Stay Night: Unlimited Blade Works visual novel (VN) into a two-season anime series! The GLORIOUS artwork, animation and soundtracks easily put it among my top 3 favorite anime series in this decade!
My favorite character is Archer: the unique design, the calmness, the no-nonsense attitude, the sarcasm, cynicism, assessments of others, and even "old-man talk" (haha). I love every fight that Archer engages in in this anime. Even though he's not a 5-star Servant in terms of power, he manages to pull win after win against tough opponents by utilizing tactics --He's a symbol of "trying your best".


I must say, watching Ufotable's adaptation is much more satisfying than reading the VN, because I get to see the most fantastic, epic, eye-pleasing battles that one can ever see in the anime world. I also get to see the characters' movements and interactions - which I can only imagine in my head when reading the VN. I also am extremely pleased to see that Ufotable's adaptation stay faithful to the original VN work! Although all internal monologues are cut out, the anime - through its amazing animation - successfully conveys all the subtleties in the ways the characters interact and fight.


There is no other company that I would entrust this franchise to. I am looking forward to Ufotable's adaption of Fate/Stay Night: Heaven's Feel. I also hope that they will adapt Fate/Hollow Ataraxia soon!


My favorite OST is EMIYA theme ! Absolutely epic!

i saw fate/zero and now i finished UBW and in this review im going to review its s1/s2
compared to fate/zero, UBW is slower and less exciting. it is more focused on story telling unlike the exciting suspenseful action packed episodes of fate/zero. there was a lot mroe talking in UBW. i was getting bored with this anime halfway but the story was great so i kept watching. i didnt really like the characters as much, but there were a few good ones introduced. 
overall i would recommend you watch this anime if you are a fan of the fate series. it's actually a must watch.the story was great, animation was great, characters were great. the only downside was that fate/zero set the bar wayyy too high so i was not as hyped watching through UBW but it was still great nonetheless. the last 5 or so episodes in s2 were the best ones in my opinion. this anime had a lot of good, memorable moments and characters

First of all, I have not read the visual novels and am not a Fate franchise fan. I've heard its name a lot and decided to give a shot for it. I watched Fate/Zero, then Unlimited Blade Works.
No spoiler review.
Story 6:
I honestly think the story has good ideas, however I think they are poorly executed. Since I came after watching Fate/zero, there were less twists involved, but still it had pretty decent ideas. However pacing, especially between the first and the second season, is quite bad. It is not that it is boring, it's just that they spend screen time on things that don't needthat much screen time.

And some moments of the plot is downright not working. I had particular difficulty watching "yet again saved by the character X at the last moments", after a certain point they stopped making any sense.


Art 9:

I am not an artist but I enjoyed what I have seen.


Sound 8:

It contributed to the overall "epic" feeling of the show pretty well.


Character 4:


I think the main characters are ok, except shirou. However the show does a lot of injustice to side characters, and there were number of them which had enormous potential to be entertaining. You might think that this injustice doesn't enough to grade as 4. I believe it does because when you have 7 masters and thus 7 servants that you can introduce and develop, if you are introducing only three or four of them in the same fashion throughout the story, that's simply poor character developpement. It doesn't really matter how well you do with the already introduced four, well it does, but part of the reason I am grading this so low is that I don't believe that the protagonists are properly introduced.

Rin was ok in my opinion, she didn't change much, but she didn't need to change much as well. 

Saber was humiliated in my opinion. One of the reasons why I graded high Fate/Zero was their capacity to portray a strong woman with no apparent weakness. This was not the case in this one. 

Archer, was real and comprehensible, but a little repetitive.

Shirou, was mediocre. I would like him if it was not for the last episodes or two. Towards the ending his epiphany moments ceased to be enlightening. He simply repeated what he had said two episodes ago. His whole attitude can be summed up as "I know I am stupid, but..." which is kind a okay for 1 or 2 times, but it can not be the driving cause of the character developpement.


Enjoyment 6:

I got bored towards the ending, but it was not soooo bad.


Overall 6:

Besides the character developpement, it was kind of a good show, but could have been way better.

The highly acclaimed Fate/Stay Night: Unlimited Blade Works is back!  Before I get started, I'm right this review having watched Fate/Stay Zero and not Fate/Stay night (2006).  Obviously, since this is a sequel, this anime would be crippled as a stand-alone, and I highly recommend you see the first season before starting this.
Story: Adequate Enough
First of all, compared to all the other branches of the Fate/Stay franchise, this anime by far, best explores the fate universe and the Servant and Master mechanics, especially the mechanics.  This anime goes as far as to explain how nothing in this universe is set in stone:the hidden secrets of the Grail and its counterparts, the conditions pertaining to servant and master, and the limits of mana.  However, this is where the story makes its sacrifices.  To explain the greater scope of the story, the plot suffers greatly.  Potential plot lines are abridged, or avoided altogether.  Potential supporting character developments are cut short when, excuse the minor spoiler, the story decides to kill off a character to avoid another story and refocus the plot revolving around our two unreliable protagonists.  I understand that the anime is based on a VN, with multiple story plots, but that does give an excuse for the anime to rush to its plot.\n
Art: Outstanding\n
Do i need to say more?  Why is this anime called Unlimited Blade Works instead of Unlimited Budget Works?  The animation by ufotable is as astonishing as ever.  Every action scene involving the Servants were very entertaining to watch and the motions flowed through wonderfully.  Even the Masters, whose powers were not as overwhelming as their servant's, came to life in their battle scenes.  Outside the action, character designs were on point, and the scenery: I paused a few times to enjoy the beautiful view.  Keep it up ufotable!\n
Character: Fair\n
To be blunt, it's no surprise to anyone that a Servant's existence is temporal and a tool to advance the plot to its grandiose ending.  Because of that, we don't know much about each Servan't backstory or their historic upbringing, except those who manage to survive until the near end.  To give credit, the demise of a couple, specific servants really does delve deep into the reasons of their actions and personality.  The supporting cast did not really leave much of an impression and there simply wasn't enough time to learn about the other masters.  But to be fair, the most important character development belongs our protagonists: Emiya Shirou and Tohsaka Rin. As I mentioned before, these two are unreliable protagonists and complicates this already intricate anime.  These two behave as polar opposites consistently throughout the anime, and by the end, establish a strong relationship.\n
Overall: Ehh, not bad\n
What this anime has going for itself is its excellent animation and reputation based on its franchise.  It's like someone had an immense imagination but only had one canvas to paint it. I enjoyed this anime and would recommend it to others, but I can not disregard its lacking details.\n

I will get straight into the point. I felt that everything about this season of the anime was great such as the music, visuals etc. The story itself has always been solid but the thing that has held back the two seasons were a few characters with one being the main man Shirou himself. His character is so poorly written, very annoying and has dumb ideals and sometimes says stuff so unbearable to watch which i wont mention due to spoilers. However some parts of his story were great which was near the end but it doesn't stop me from feeling bored and frustrated wheneveri see him. I know its only one flaw im talking about but this specific point is what i feel holds back the series unlike Fate/Zero. Other than him, there are others like Shinji but he's a minor so its alright. There are good and very cool/likable characters but again i dont want to spoil anything. On the postive the fight scenes were incredible and stunning and the opening is arguably one of the best i've seen. Despite the weak main character Shriou, i still found Fate UBW awesome and exciting to watch but i just wanted to explain my one frustration of the series. \n\n
i would give this an 8.5 btw.

This continuation Fate/stay night: Unlimited Blade Works takes us further in the adaption of the route in the visual novel. 
The story this time around develops very well, having an amazing ending, and the character development of our main protagonist is executed in a very good way. I personally found the ending the be extremely satisfying as well, and it really fills in the earlier plot holes that were created in the first season.
The art, action and soundtrack are similarly outstanding in comparison to the first season, it doesn't get much better than this.
Overall, the enjoyment doesn't falter, and I would recommend any action lovingfan to immediately sit down and watch this one. The action will pull you in, and the story will make you stay. The action will most likely make you stay regardless though, so...

In this route of Fate Stay Night Shiro developed his personality much better than in the adaptation of Studio Deen, where the ideals that he longed for, following his interpretation of what it was to be a hero from his father's teachings, Love for his newcomer. This time Shiro went ahead and actually loculated the gap left in the first adaptation, showing how far he was shaped by his misinterpretation of how and to be a hero, from his father. The story of the Archer also helped make the character much more mature, and much deeper, thus giving a sort of "reality clash" in whatwas a personification of his [Archer] father with his [idealistic] personality.\n\n
This adaptation really is a remedy to forget his first, so we can see how Kiritsugu [the best character in the franchise, in my opinion] was important, being a hero not legendary, who ended up personified in the person of the Archer, who by End, ended up getting into friction with his ideal in the form of the wandering Shiro. Really a very dignified series. Although this adaptation has its shortcomings, development compared to the first is much better. Fate / Zero for me is the best Fate of all, and my personal reference.

This will be a review for S1 and S2, since I watched this as a whole. There might be some spoilers so you are warned.
Other point before I start is that my review is based only on the anime versions, I never read any of the VN or played the games related to the Fate universe. That being so, let's start.
I have to say that during the time I was watching this I was really hooked to it, I watched it all almost in one go, and I liked so much that I gave it a 9/10 score. 
At the time that I'm writing thisreview it's been some months, and I have to say that now I would lower my score to a 7/10 just because there are moments in the story that are quite forgetful. That's not what you want from a great anime.


The story leads us to a world where everything is set in motion for the Holy Grail War, we have our main character Emiya Shirou, a high school student that is somehow dragged into this world of magic and servants. There are seven masters for seven servants from seven different classes: Saber, Archer, Lancer, Rider, Caster, Assassin and Berserker. Each of the seven masters will fight each other in order to gain the Holy Grail. Shirou, however is the type of selfless person that makes a lot of mistakes and puts himself in danger when there were other ways of dealing with the problems, he want to be the hero of justice and that's great and all, but sometimes he's just stupid. That is what happens in most of S1, Shirou doing everything he can to save everyone, bu putting everyone in danger. 

S2 I have to say that I really liked the way it turned out. In this season there is a big twist regarding Archer, that somehow made this into a great show for me. That was a surprise and the one thing i will remember from this show.

I was a great ending and just for that I would recommend it.


The art is just amazing, it's really really good, specially in the fight scenes. The backgrounds are detailed and always add to the feeling of the show. The animation if fluid, the colors are on point, really nothing bad to say here. The fight scenes are just amazing, probably the best ones I've seen in a long time.


The sound is quite good also. The opening of S1 is very good, usually I skip the Op, but I was listening to this one. The Eds are not so memorable, but still in accordance to the show. 

The background music was also very good, adding to the feeling of the story.


The characters are the difficult part here, since the most memorable ones are not the main ones. Emiya Shirou and Thonsaka Rin are our main characters, I liked Rin in the beginning, she looked like a strong and independent girl that could handle herself well, but after some interaction with Shirou she starts to feel more like a damsel in distress then what I though. 

For me the best characters are Saber and Archer, specially Archer, he really comes a long way, and in the end is the main protagonist in this whole story, at least in my opinion. Saber is Shirou's Servant and she's a bad ass. Like Archer, she's the one that ends up doing everything to save the masters in distress. 

The other Servants are also very good, just wished there was more development there. Also from the other masters. 


I really enjoyed the show, it's a nice take on good vs evil, and on how to keep sacrificing yourself for other leads to people taking advantage of you. I would recommend Fate/stay nigh Unlimited blade works to fans of this genre, if you like good animated fights and if you like anime that have a ending, as in you feel like it's over.

Now I have watched plenty of anime in my time, and while this is not my absolute favorite, it has made it into my top five. A little background, I tried to watch Fate/Zero but it was hard to get into in the first few episodes, based on the fact that I can be a simple anime fan. I like to know who the main characters are and what they go up against. In Fate/Zero, there were simply so many characters to keep track of that it was confusing to say the least. 
But onto Unlimited Blade Works . . . I loved this show.Not only did it have great art and animation, the story line was strong as well. The whole dynamic of Rin and Shirou fighting together, with Archer and Saber and Lancer even, was just fantastic.


Not only was this anime visually appealing, but it was emotionally appealing as well. The entire fight between Archer and Shirou was more than just a flashy piece of great animation, it expressed a battle of will and a determination to accomplish a goal even knowing the outcome. That sequence of episodes was some of the greatest symbolic piece I have ever seen in an anime. 


While I thoroughly enjoyed it, I would have to agree that it is not perfect. My biggest concern was Rin and Shirou's relationship. I believe they probably could have played this factor more, even though it was not a romance anime. Also I would have liked more clarification at the end to end the romance part on a high note. Another discrepancy is Kirei's part in this, he seemed to be a major villain throughout the entire series and is finished off very quickly.


I give this anime a 9/10 with great animation, story line, likable characters, and underlying meaning as well. It reached my top 5 anime and will most likely stay there for a while.

gg ufotable, you blew us away with Season 2 (sort of)
STORY- 7/10
Story-wise it got better, with the twists at the beginning of the season being vital to the rest of the plot. Gilgamesh looks even cooler in UBW than he did in Fate/Zero, we get some interesting backstories and more character development, nice job UBW. Shirou still says weird stuff ("Just because you're correct doesn't mean you're right!"), but he's better than last season LOL.

Well yes, the art does go down a bit in quality later on in the season, but then you should look at DEEN's movie adaption of UBW and you'd seewhy this still deserves a 10. The Archer vs Lancer rematch was godly though, won't deny that.\n\n

Well, turns out that Yuki Kajiura helped out with the music (something I missed last season), and after watching DEEN's adaption, I must say that the music is pretty good. And of course, the Fate veterans have been voice-acting this one for a while now, so their voices are on point. Once again, this score was influenced by the godly Archer vs Lancer rematch.\n\n

HOORAY SHIROU ISN'T A COMPLETE IDIOT ANYMORE WOOHOO CELEBRATE. Yeah, Shirou gets some development, Rin kinda goes Tsundere but it doesn't affect the general plot too much. OVERALL- 8/10\n
